en.value: We left the house and then [k]walked[/k] to the shop.
What did he actually do? I don't know the full story. Did he fall off his [k]mountain bike[/k]?
The sun [k]was shining[/k] and we all went swimming in the sea.
Don't touch the cactus or you'll prick yourself.
mountain bike
[k]In the end[/k] I left the restaurant without paying.
I fainted and fell onto the floor.
Maria
I only saw her for two minutes; she left [k]just after[/k] I got there.
As soon as we got there it started to rain.
The river is perfect for rafting.
Narrative tenses - never go
We like canyoning very much.
In the garden
It [k]had rained[/k] all night and the grass was wet.

When writing or telling stories we often link the different actions together with linking words. These can tell us about the order that events happened in and any relationship between events in the story.
petal
Then the door opened and we all jumped out.
Why waste money? I am capable of cutting the grass and watering the [k]plants[/k]! And I actually enjoy it.
lawn
Let's go surfing!
leaf
flower
We love hiking in the mountains.
Water the plants.
We generally use Past Continuous tense to talk about longer actions happening at the same time as the main events.
Describing your garden and your favourite adventure sports
bungee-jumping
We had all made food and brought it to the park.
Yes, we were very careful this trip. But I guess that's the risk you take with adventure sports.
We talked and laughed and ate all day.
As soon as we got there it started to rain. We sheltered under the tree but we still got wet. Finally, as it was getting dark, the rain stopped.
We [k]had never been|had never gone[/k] to Spain before and we were very excited.
Pick up the leaves that have fallen.
Select the words in the correct order.
and I fell onto the floor.
Past Simple is formed with the Past Simple form of the verb
I had never been in an aeroplane before.
I've got lots of work to do here! First, I've got to mow the [k]lawn[/k].
Lie down on the grass.
I hadn't eaten anything all day.
I would most like...because..., ... is the most exciting to me because I love...., I've always wanted to try .....
Then I realised that I [k]had left[/k] my passport on the bed.
Help the gardener.
The plane was climbing higher and higher in the sky.
Past Perfect is formed with had + past participle
had walked

The sun was shining and everyone was happy.
We had all made food and brought it to the park.
We talked and laughed and ate all day.
The sentence is Past Simple tense.
to water
OK, but if you want we could get my brother over to give you a hand.
We often combine different past tenses to tell stories about the past. Past Simple, Past Continuous and Past Perfect are all known as narrative tenses.
Narrative tenses - not be
kayaking
thrilling
hiking
Past Continuous is formed with was/were + -ing form of verb
You like kayaking.
Narrative tenses - already wait
We use different narrative tenses for different reasons.
Look after the plants.
[k]The plane[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]climbing[/k] [k]higher and higher[/k] [k]in the sky.[/k]
rafting
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the correct option.
The sentence contains two different tenses.
Finally, as it was getting dark, the rain stopped.
The experience was thrilling!
Grammar: Narrative tenses
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
They love going out with their mountain bikes.
Fill in the gap using the hint.
Smell the flowers.
We sheltered under the tree but we still got wet.
They're going on a surfing holiday.
shone
You love bungee-jumping.
Look at the coloured petals.
Narrative tenses - leave
It [k]was not|wasn't[/k] a good start to our honeymoon.
grass
Right, I'll ask him to come here and I'll look after his children for the afternoon.
The sun was shining and everyone was happy.
After
We got there early but people [k]were already waiting[/k] in the queue.
Be careful though. Last time you did the gardening you hurt your back and had to have a few days off work!
plant
James
John
climbing
[k]I had[/k] [k]never been[/k] [k]in an aeroplane before[/k] [k]and I was[/k] [k]very scared.[/k]
before
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
scuba diving
We got up, packed our bags and [k]left[/k] for the airport.
We use Past Simple tense to tell the main sequence of events in a story.
[k]While[/k] we were preparing dinner, they called and cancelled.
Luckily we [k]had paid for[/k] priority boarding when we booked and we went straight to the front.
Julia
Last time I was [k]planting[/k] trees and bushes though. This is a much smaller job. Don't worry, I'll be fine.
Narrative tenses - pay for
What adventure sport would you most or least like to try? Why?
OK, good idea. He knows a lot about [k]flowers[/k] and he can help me with the [k]grass[/k] too.
How was your trip John? Did you have a good time?
I go rock climbing every week.
True or false?
cactus
Oh dear, that's terrible. I guess it shows the importance of being careful and wearing necessary [k]safety equipment[/k].
Yes, it's a real shame. Hopefully he'll recover soon though. Maybe he can come along next time.
The phrases in bold relate to time or order of events.
canyoning
gardener
He is mowing the lawn.
Adventure sports
Why don't we just hire a [k]gardener[/k]! It'll save us a lot of trouble!
It was amazing. One week wasn't long enough! We went [k]climbing[/k] and did some amazing [k]hiking[/k]. But two weeks would have been better.
They don't like scuba diving.
rains
[k]Then[/k] [k]the door opened[/k] [k]and[/k] [k]we all[/k] [k]jumped out.[/k]
That sounds so good. It's a shame your brother couldn't go with you, he would have loved that.
At first
No. He went [k]surfing[/k] last month and a wave pushed him into some rocks. It was quite scary.
surfing
The waiters were preparing our table,
We usually use Past Perfect tense to talk about events that happened before or leading up to the main events.
